author: potuz
content:
Great, thanks! yeah indeed there's several aspects in which you can help. If you're interested in the specification side, some people have complains that I don't even consider valid  about bipasseability, others about whether ePBS should happen or not, I don't want to get there.  The biggest actual problem with the current design is about reorg resistance against colluding parties. Currently a proposer is safe against 1-slot ex-anti reorgs up to against an attacker controlling 40% of the stake.  In the current specification this goes down to 20% assuming the attacker controls also the network splits as he wants. Some immediate action points:
- Check that in fact the 20% assertion is correct  in the analized cases.
- Study the spec to see if there are better attack scenarios that reduce the 20% threshold. 
- Write down the complete situation for multiple slot reorgs, wether the attacker can keep the payloads, what are the thresholds etc. 
- Check if there are better solutions with stronger forkchoice guarantees

Other action points are as follows. I will open the full python spec PR for review this week, currently it's fairly advanced but forkchoice is missing a big chunk and the APIs have some copy-paste text that needs to be removed. Once that's up (or now as long as it's on the fully ready files):
- Review the python spec PR. 
- Check that indeed the spec conforms to what it's written in the design doc
- Check that everything in the design doc is actually covered in the python spec.
- Check if there are more edge cases to consider.
